body: @himanshug it surfaced in practice while we were qualifying 0.9.1

@drcrallen I agree that you noticed worker running over capacity but I am just trying to think of other things that could cause the issue besides the race described.

@gianm can you confirm , that when announceTask(..) method exits , zkWorkers would be guaranteed to have updated view of that worker running the new task? I think it is , but just confirming.
I think similar work is done in some other PRs, will take a look at those and will reopen if needed.
Just FYI, be wary of https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3187 whenever (if ever) introspection is enabled for this extension.

druid.storage.bucket=myBucket
druid.storage.baseKey=newdruid/segments

This will log two messages a second if the buffer is full‚Ä¶¬†seems like a lot, perhaps add a throttle (up to you)?

üëç  otherwise though
üëç
üëç

@gianm i guess it will be fine... printing of that log is really an exceptional situation... if that log is getting printed too much then that is an indication that something bad will eventually happen and more partitions,  tunings, hardware etc etc is needed to support the input data rate.

I just realized that since this is called by jetty threads, it will potentially log a lot more often than twice a second. Also this situation is not really that bad if it's a temporary situation (perhaps buffer is full due to a data rate spike/backlog, and you have QoS enabled to protect queries so they will be OK).

So for those two reasons I do think we should have a throttle here.
i did not factor in the multiple threads too, let me throttle it to print every 10 retries instead of each one
IMO a time based throttle is best, like at most one message every 10 seconds or something.

10/20 retries would equal to 5/10 secs as wait time is hardcoded to be 500ms..

or, do you mean once every 10 secs across all threads, that would need some global variables to be kept, not sure if we want to go that route ?

or instead of "log" we can introduce a new metric for this case

e.g. ingest/buffer/failCount  and update it on each failed "add" call?
I meant once every 10 seconds across all threads, using an AtomicLong in the firehose. A metric works too. Metrics are also shared AtomicLongs so I think they're kinda similar in that regard.

IMHO your proposed solution 1 is the correct one: 

`change logic of HadoopDruidIndexerConfig.makeIntermediatePath() to generate a unique directory name each time`

fix the intermediate path to generate something that is unique per job.
Finally got around to checking this out. I think your proposed solution in the original issue (to ensure unique intermediate paths per job) is the correct one.

üëç 

agree these are a bit confusing, the druid configs are kind of out of date and I think the hadoop configs have a bunch of stuff in them that was never really relevant to druid. we also have cluster-ready configs in the tarball now https://github.com/druid-io/druid/tree/master/examples/conf

I'm torn on this in a few ways:
1. Imply and MMX both benefit from not having suggested configurations in the wild (this is an argument for having another party comment on this)
2. Best config values vary GREATLY depending on actual production workload. 
3. The configurations are pretty out dated (m1.large, wat?)
4. We should strive as a community to make default configs pretty good for most use cases, especially just starting up use cases.
5. The configs are explained better and in more detail elsewhere in the docs.
6. I have no interest in maintaining these configs as time goes on.
7.  If we need to have example config files or suggested templates, I think in the quickstart is a better place to host them.

So in general I'm üëç  but have a conflict of interest here so would like to hear if these docs to be removed are useful for anyone in the community before zapping them completely.

I actually have no problem with having a good starting point for production configs out there. I don't think Imply stands to gain anything from having suboptimal defaults ‚Äì¬†if anything we really want people to have a great experience benchmarking Druid out of the box.

I agree with your (2), (3), (4), (5), (6), and (7) though @drcrallen :)

Personally I think it's best to focus on,
- https://github.com/druid-io/druid/tree/master/examples/conf-quickstart as a good set of defaults for a single-machine setup,
- https://github.com/druid-io/druid/tree/master/examples/conf as a good set of defaults for a cluster,
- and the reference docs explain all the other options for people that want to really get into it.

:+1:
I agree with @gianm here regarding focusing on quick start and make it such that extending that into production configuration is  a matter of updating key config values.

as far as suggested configuration is concerned, my experience is that there is no single good answer there... it greatly depends upon the use case, batch/realtime ingestion time , ingestion and query load.  we have various clusters with fairly different production configuration.

Just to add color to this issue. The expression that filed was:

```
"function(d){_1=(_1=(_1=d,(_1==null?null:_1.length)),(_1==null?null:Math.floor(_1 / 10) * 10));return isNaN(_1)?null:_1}"
```

And turns out that the global `_1` was being polluted. As a JavaScript programmer I felt betrayed that there is a possibility that another thread was running during the execution of my code.
Look what you made me do: https://github.com/implydata/plywood/pull/121
@hamlet-lee are you setting `uniqueId` for the hadoop ingestion spec? if not, then `schema.getUniqueId()` should be doing what you are proposing
Note this was added in druid 0.9.0
I moved the rollup option from DataSchema to the new NoRollupGranularitySpec whose queryGranularity is always none, and updated the ingestion/index.md, @fjy

@drcrallen schema.getUniqueId() seems not unique enough.  Consecutive calling getUniqueId() do not always produce different intermediate paths.  So "determine" and "index" task may conflict. This is one cause of this issue.

~~I am not 100% sure if this is a right change because I cannot track down related changes anymore further (from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/commit/7e7a886f65743c2a4b1750feca43750aea68413a)~~ Could you please take a look? @gianm 

`StringInputRowParser` is deprecated here https://github.com/druid-io/druid-api/commit/2383c142c41e791665729585ac45441795129de2 and `JSONParseSpec` was deprecated here, https://github.com/druid-io/druid-api/commit/b62a147880d5ce635f296044f1d5ad002fe862e8. I assume (from those commits) this change was missed during porting this.

I cannot unfortunately share the sample I used as it contains user information. I will try to replicate the problem with another datasource and provide you a sample later this week.

However, in the meantime, I can give you a bit more information about the data. The schema of the dimension I am trying to ingest is the following:

```
"type":"record",
"name":"XXXX",
"namespace":"XXXX",
"fields":[
      ....
      {
         "name":"session_status",
         "type":
            {
               "type":"array",
               "items":"string"
            },
         "doc":"Status of the session record"
      },
      ...
```

I tried verifying I could indeed read the field properly from Scala. Using the following code works (rec: GenericRecord) for me:

```
rec.get("session_status").asInstanceOf[GenericData.Array[String]].toList
```

And it returns me the correct values regardless of the number of entries in the array.

Hi, just to mirror some of the discussion from here https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-user/kZVNO0MgCs4:

We have a CDH 5.3.3 Hadoop cluster and have set up our extensions such that we use the CDH 5.3.3 jars for the HDFS extension as well as the default hadoop coordinates.  Batch reingestion works well after setting `hadoop.mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first=true`, but we have intermittent realtime ingestion task failures.  We replicate our realtime ingestion tasks (2 total) and one of the replicas will fail with the following exception:


üëç

this seems to be introducing a regression for fill capacity worker selection strategy. 
with single assignment thread + fill capacity worker selection strategy, all the tasks get assigned to same worker until its capacity gets filled and only when a worker is filled to its capacity tasks are assigned to next worker. 

With above patch, with multiple assignment threads and fill capacity worker select strategy, it is possible that each assignment thread will assign tasks to a separate worker even though none of them is filled to their capacity. 

This may not affect most of the setups practically, but it theoretically alters the contract for worker selection strategy.

@sirpkt

I tested this patch (on top of druid master) against a few hadoop remote clusters, using a batch ingestion task with S3 as both input and deep storage.

Running without `hadoop.mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first=true` configured on the middleManager, the ingestion task failed on the following hadoop versions:

```
sequenceIQ docker images: 
2.3.0 through 2.5.2
Error: com.google.inject.util.Types.collectionOf(Ljava/lang/reflect/Type;)Ljava/lang/reflect/ParameterizedType;

2.6.0, 2.7.1:
Error: class com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype.guava.deser.HostAndPortDeserializer overrides final method deserialize.(Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/core/JsonParser;Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/databind/DeserializationContext;)Ljava/lang/Object;

Amazon EMR:
task succeeded

cloudera 5.7.0.0 docker (2.6.0):
Error: class com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype.guava.deser.HostAndPortDeserializer overrides final method deserialize.(Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/core/JsonParser;Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/databind/DeserializationContext;)Ljava/lang/Object;

hortonworks 2.4 sandbox (2.7.1):
Error: class com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype.guava.deser.HostAndPortDeserializer overrides final method deserialize.(Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/core/JsonParser;Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/databind/DeserializationContext;)Ljava/lang/Object;
```

If i configure `hadoop.mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first=true`, then the ingestion task succeeds on all of those versions.
`hadoop.mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first` doesn't strike me as something we should be advocating by default.

- 2.6.0 and 2.7.1 failed with error:

```
Error: class com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype.guava.deser.HostAndPortDeserializer overrides final method deserialize.(Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/core/JsonParser;Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/databind/DeserializationContext;)Ljava/lang/Object;
```

EMR works.

Cloudera 5.7.0.0 (2.6.0) and Hortonworks Sandbox 2.4 (2.7.1) fail with 

```
Error: class com.fasterxml.jackson.datatype.guava.deser.HostAndPortDeserializer overrides final method deserialize.(Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/core/JsonParser;Lcom/fasterxml/jackson/databind/DeserializationContext;)Ljava/lang/Object;
```

@kaijianding I don't think we need a new type of granularity spec, I think the default (uniform granularity spec) should have the option of turning rollup off right now. The uniform granularity spec currently has the parameter queryGranularity which controls how data gets rolled up.

I started digging to try and find what's causing the conflict, but hadoop uses `org.codehaus.jackson` not `com.fasterxml.jackson`

This error should only be caused by something pulling in `com.fasterxml.jackson.core:jackson-databind` older than `2.4.0`.

I went through and excluded all the things which were even referencing jackson.core: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3225  @jon-wei can you try that branch and see if it fixes things?

Otherwise we need to figure out what's pulling in an old version of jackson-databind
@drcrallen can we avoid the milestone until we have more milestones this approach will work?
